Fiona, I'm not talking about you (whoever you are) and your 11 year old web=
 site.=C2=A0 I'm responding to your comment "I know one person who paid him=
 for a reading; it definitely did not 
involve "hundreds of dollars an hour=
." 

Well, it sounds like that person got a sweet discount from his normal =
prices of $300/hour.



--- On Thu, 6/17/10, Fiona Broome <email@fionabroom=
e.com> wrote:

From: Fiona Broome <email@...>
Subject: [EVP-ITC=
] Re: Tesing-testing
To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thursday, June 17, 2=
010, 11:26 AM







=C2=A0



  


    
      
      
      Hi,



Well, y=
es, and five years ago, I was getting $3k for being one of the speakers at =
weekend events.  The economy changes, sometimes dramatically, and our fees =
change accordingly.



These days, most of what we do includes paying out-o=
f-pocket for gas or airfare, plus motels of dubious distinction, en route. =
 At about 80% of events, no speaker's fee is involved. (In case you're wond=
ering, the hotel or other meeting rooms where events are hosted... that's w=
here most of the money goes.)



Guest appearances on reality TV shows rare=
ly pay anything at all. (Not such a great "reality"... huh? *chuckle and si=
gh*)  However, a TV appearance is a credential that can (usually just brief=
ly) allow us to charge more for our services.



In boom or bust, we keep d=
oing what we do. We aspire to earn enough when times are good, to keep the =
bills paid when they're not so great.



I don't know anyone in this field =
who wouldn't rather be doing something else, preferably with a steady paych=
eck.  We do this because we can't NOT do it.  If anyone is getting rich in =
this field, I have yet to meet them.



I don't want sympathy, but I also d=
on't want someone digging through my 11+ year old website, finding a page w=
ith my old fees, and deciding I'm doing this for the money. 



I'm on this=
 list to learn about the box, and similar devices.  I want to understand wh=
at they do, why we hear impossibly consistent voices on them, how to improv=
e the results, and what the significance of this is.



I can't remain sile=
nt when someone suggests that a fellow researcher is money motivated.  But =
really, let's get back on-topic.



Sincerely,

Fiona

>

> Yes it is going off topic, but=
 just to make sure all the facts are here:

> - Mr Moon does solicit cl=
ients and charge for readings.=C3=82=C2=A0

      <p>Hi,<br>

ars ago, I was getting $3k for being one of the speakers at weekend events.=
  The economy changes, sometimes dramatically, and our fees change accordin=
gly.<br>
<br>
These days, most of what we do includes paying out-of-pocket =
for gas or airfare, plus motels of dubious distinction, en route.  At about=
 80% of events, no speaker's fee is involved. (In case you're wondering, th=
e hotel or other meeting rooms where events are hosted... that's where most=
 of the money goes.)<br>
<br>
Guest appearances on reality TV shows rarely =
pay anything at all. (Not such a great "reality"... huh? *chuckle and sigh*=
)  However, a TV appearance is a credential that can (usually just briefly)=
 allow us to charge more for our services.<br>
<br>
In boom or bust, we kee=
p doing what we do. We aspire to earn enough when times are good, to keep t=
he bills paid when they're not so great.<br>
<br>
I don't know anyone in th=
is field who wouldn't rather be doing something else, preferably with a ste=
ady paycheck.  We do this because we can't NOT do it.  If anyone is getting=
 rich in this field, I have yet to meet them.<br>
<br>
I don't want sympath=
y, but I also don't want someone digging through my 11+ year old website, f=
inding a page with my old fees, and deciding I'm doing this for the money. =

I'm on this list to learn about the box, and similar devices.  I =
want to understand what they do, why we hear impossibly consistent voices o=
n them, how to improve the results, and what the significance of this is.<b=
r>
